ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned about Inca culture and the history of Peru.  I also learned how to skim articles and find more efficient ways to understand writings.

This class taught me a lot about Inca Culture and history. I think this is an amazing class where you can engage with someone who is has such a rich immersion with the culture. Prof Burger is an amazing storyteller and he really weaves his stories and personal experiences in the andes with the larger themes of the class.
Survey of Inca empire, its material culture, and a larger understanding of the Spanish Conquest's consequences for Modern-day Peru.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: 
- Fun, enjoyable, and not a ton of work. Nice 5th class. 
- I learned a lot
- Professor was genuinely interested in the subject
Weaknesses: 
- Kind of disorganized at times
- Class wasn't super engaging
- Didn't get feedback in a timely manner (for essays)

The strength were that it was very engaging class. It was more of a leminar format, but it was very entertaining to listen to him talk and explain lots of these aspects of Inca culture. He would also share artifacts he's gotten over time. I think it could be improved by weighing in more on student engagement and participation. there were times when he would talk for the entire time slot and no one else would contribute anything because there wasn't really space for it.

Strengths: Richard Burger is supremely knowledgeable about the Inca empire (and Peruvian archaeology in general). He is an absolute legend and, frankly, there are very little scholars in the world who are better to learn from. His lectures are engaging and I always leave feeling like I have learned something new. The class is super interesting and finds ways to connect the story of the Incas and their archaeology to current Peruvian life/culture. 

Weaknesses: I actually have no idea what my grade is currently in the class. Burger also does not use slides with text written on them so you really have to pay attention and type quickly to take notes (this is fine but something to note if this is something that historically bothers you). It is hard to figure out what to read for a given class or to know what assignment guidelines are sometimes (for example sometimes you will find three different length requirements on canvas for a given assignment; however, this can be easily remedied by simply asking Burger yourself).

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, as a non-archaeology student, I found this course to be accessible and interesting.  I feel like I'm coming out of it with a broader understanding of the course, without having to do a ton of work/ busy work.  Readings were genuinely interesting and the content was cool.
Yes, definitely! This was a great class and it's very much fun to listen to the stories that Prof Burger has.
I would definitely recommend this course to someone who is interested in Inca archaeology and learning from the field's most prominent scholar
